p: In search of a mechanism for how exactly αSyn may affect vesicle biology, the Südhof group proposed that αSyn acts as a chaperone for Synaptobrevin-2 (VAMP-2) [ 44], thereby increasing the number of assembled soluble N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive factor attachment protein receptor (SNARE) complexes. However, it was also shown that αSyn can inhibit membrane fusion by directly affecting the lipid bilayer, rather than indirectly via SNARE proteins [ 45, 46].
